title: Fixing Relative Directory for Workdir and File Mounts (`~/sky_workdir/...` not `~/sky_workdir/workdir/...`)
body: Fixes #442 The original PR #431 addressed symlinks by rsyncing only the symbolic link IF the specified filemount/workdir is a symbolic link. These changes introduced a new bug, which alters with `workdir` and `filemounts` dirs are located relative to mount path. This is due to `rsync ~/Downloads/temp server:/sky` vs `rsync ~/Downloads/temp/ server:/sky` having very different behaviors. Problem 1: Choosing `rsync ~/Downloads/temp server:/sky` results in `~/sky_workdir/workdir/...` which is bad. Problem 2: Choosing `rsync ~/Downloads/temp/ server:/sky` affects symbolic links. if ` ~/Downloads/temp/` is a symlink, `rsync ~/Downloads/temp/ server:/sky` uploads the symlink's target folder contents. This PR achieves a compromise between these two problems. When the workdir/source path is a symlink, it will `rsync ~/Downloads/temp server:/sky` and upload nothing onto the server (except for symlink). Otherwise (not a symlink normal dir), it will ``rsync ~/Downloads/temp/ server:/sky` ## Tests - [x] Passes `examples/using_file_mounts.yaml` - [x] Passes `examples/resnet_app_storage.yaml` (Tests the relative placement of workdir and file mounts such as all the TF record files in `/tmp/imagenet/...` for training)

title: Remove tracebacks for exceptions to improve UX
body:
Previously, the raised exceptions will print a large amount of unnecessary traceback information of the internal sky code as well `ssh` error, so that the user's file_mounts / setup / run error will be more close to the end and easier to find. This PR suppresses the errors that occurred in the following yaml. Closes #384 .
```yaml
# workdir: ~/not-exits

# file_mounts:
#  /not-exists: ./examples
#  ~/test: ~/not-exits

resources:
  cloud: aws

setup: |
  echo "running setup"
  # python -c "raise RuntimeError('setup failed')"

run: |
  echo "started"
  python -c "raise RuntimeError('run failed')"
```

The following is an output example of setup failure:

title: Gcloud Authentication Bug Fix
body: Resolves P0 Issue #321 . Tl;dr 1) Start on a completely new machine, 2) Install Sky/GCP and set up credentials, 3) Run `sky launch examples/using_file_mounts.yaml` -> Bug: Gcloud is initializing for the first time, it will add additional logs to the process output in the `is_directory()` method in `cloud_stores.py`. Precisely it will look like this: Correct Output: `out=gs://cloud-tpu-test-datasets/fake_imagenet/train-00001-of-01024` Fix: If the code detects the Gcloud intro message in the output, run again. It will go away the second time.

title: Remove `-i` for `bash user_script.sh`
body:
After more investigation into the bash options, we can now remove the `-i` option for `bash user_script.sh` by adding `set -a` before we do `. $(conda info --base)/etc/profile.d/conda.sh 2> /dev/null || true`. This reduce the burden from the user side as mentioned in #422 and #390 .

Reference: https://www.gnu.org/software/bash/manual/html_node/The-Set-Builtin.html

Tested:
- [x] `sky launch -c dth examples/resnet_distributed_torch_with_script.yaml`
- [x] `sky launch -c examples/env_check.yaml`

title: New formatter

labels.name: do not merge
labels.description: do not merge this PR now

body:
New formatter used by Ray.

Benefits:
1. More strict check, hint bugs
2. More beautiful code format
3. Modern style (88 line width)
4. Less tests (combine lint+check)

Close https://github.com/sky-proj/sky/issues/309

The new linter discovers a bug that pylint failed to capture: https://github.com/sky-proj/sky/blob/d71e2d21dd90a2cd99961102fd6704955ed03e3f/sky/data/storage.py#L580-L581

title: [Storage] `sky storage delete` for Public Buckets
body:
Deleting public buckets on `S3` will hang if the bucket is super big (it tries to delete all objects and doesn't stop halfway even detecting permission error).

Hence it is difficult to delete `sky storage` logs in `sky.db` in some cases.

title: [docker] Quick fix to remove already-dead docker containers from `sky status`
body:
This PR is a quick fix for #416

Currently, `sky status` does not reflect the status change in docker containers that are externally stopped/removed (e.g., by `docker rm`).
This PR enables users to manually remove those containers by `sky stop`.

body:
If user doesn't install Azure depedencies at installation, but later tries to use Azure, the thrown error (suggesting checking credentials) is incorrect:

```
(base) romilb@romilbx1yoga:/mnt/d/Romil/Berkeley/Research/sky-experiments$ sky launch -c azure-start-stop ./examples/azure_start_stop.yaml
Task from YAML spec: ./examples/azure_start_stop.yaml
Running task on cluster azure-start-stop...
I 02-23 00:01:27 optimizer.py:213] Defaulting estimated time to 1 hr. Call Task.set_time_estimator() to override.
I 02-23 00:01:28 optimizer.py:323] Optimizer - plan minimizing cost (~$0.9):
I 02-23 00:01:28 optimizer.py:337]
I 02-23 00:01:28 optimizer.py:337] TASK              BEST_RESOURCE
I 02-23 00:01:28 optimizer.py:337] azure-start-stop  2x Azure(Standard_D8_v4)
I 02-23 00:01:28 optimizer.py:337]
I 02-23 00:01:28 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:1085] Creating a new cluster: "azure-start-stop" [2x Azure(Standard_D8_v4)].
I 02-23 00:01:28 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:1085] Tip: to reuse an existing cluster, specify --cluster-name (-c) in the CLI or use sky.launch(.., cluster_name=..) in the Python API. Run `sky status` to see ex
isting clusters.
I 02-23 00:01:28 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:657] To view detailed progress: tail -n100 -f sky_logs/sky-2022-02-23-00-01-27-344494/provision.log
I 02-23 00:01:28 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:667]
I 02-23 00:01:28 cloud_vm_ray_backend.py:667] Launching on Azure eastus ()
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/mnt/d/Romil/Berkeley/Research/sky-experiments/sky/execution.py", line 129, in _execute
    cluster_name=cluster_name)
  File "/mnt/d/Romil/Berkeley/Research/sky-experiments/sky/backends/cloud_vm_ray_backend.py", line 1134, in provision
    cluster_name)
  File "/mnt/d/Romil/Berkeley/Research/sky-experiments/sky/backends/cloud_vm_ray_backend.py", line 950, in provision_with_retries
    prev_cluster_config=prev_cluster_config)
  File "/mnt/d/Romil/Berkeley/Research/sky-experiments/sky/backends/cloud_vm_ray_backend.py", line 677, in _retry_region_zones
    cluster_name=cluster_name)
  File "/mnt/d/Romil/Berkeley/Research/sky-experiments/sky/backends/backend_utils.py", line 372, in write_cluster_config
    ) from None
RuntimeError: Fail to get subscription id from azure cli. Make sure you have login in and fix it with this Azure cli command: "az account set -s <subscription_id>".

```

The actual error is caused because azure-cli pip package is not installed (even though az login and az account -s <subscription_id> is set):

```
# In python shell
>>> from azure.common import credentials
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'azure'
```

Consequently, this import fails:

https://github.com/sky-proj/sky/blob/3f43c997ca3ffdcf7ad00000fb6d4d5407f4b5e2/sky/adaptors/azure.py#L29

But the parent try catch block is casts too wide a net and catches _all_ exceptions under the same error message:

https://github.com/sky-proj/sky/blob/3f43c997ca3ffdcf7ad00000fb6d4d5407f4b5e2/sky/backends/backend_utils.py#L352-L361

I am assuming we catch `Exception` because we're not sure of the kind of errors that can be thrown by a third party library like azure. So, the fix is probably to check for ModuleNotFoundError before going on to catching general `Exception`. We should also `raise from e` to get a better stack trace for debugging.

Reproduction:
```
pip uninstall azure-common
sky launch -c azure-start-stop ./examples/azure_start_stop.yaml
```

title: Add document for `bash script.sh` cannot do `conda activate` problem
body:
`conda activate` will generate the following error in bash script, if not properly setup. #422 
```
CommandNotFoundError: Your shell has not been properly configured to use 'conda activate'.                                                   
To initialize your shell, run                                                                                                                
                                                                                                                                             
    $ conda init <SHELL_NAME>                                                                                                                
                                                                                                                                             
Currently supported shells are:                                                                                                              
  - bash                                                                                                                                     
  - fish                                                                                                                                     
  - tcsh                                                                                                                                     
  - xonsh                                                                                                                                    
  - zsh                                                                                                                                      
  - powershell                                                                                                                               
                                                                                                                                             
See 'conda init --help' for more information and options. 
```

By some experiments,  I found that adding`. $(conda info --base)/etc/profile.d/conda.sh 2> /dev/null || true` at the end of the `~/.bashrc` and let the user do `source ~/.bashrc` at the beginning of the `user_setup.sh` will not correctly enable `conda activate`. 

The only way that will work is to add the command `. $(conda info --base)/etc/profile.d/conda.sh` at the beginning of `user_setup.sh` or let the user call their script with `bash -i user_setup.sh`.

I decided to add a comment in quickstart to let the user call `bash -i` for their own script.

title: Revert to using file_mounts for object mounting
body:
Closes #409. Here's a summary:

1. With #324, we moved any file_mount of the form `/dst/: <cloudstore>://` to use `sky.Storage` behind the scenes. This was done with the eventual vision that cloud storage will support writes, and thus cloud paths should use cloud storage.

2. However, this broke syncing single objects (e.g. `  /train-00001-of-01024: gs://cloud-tpu-test-datasets/fake_imagenet/train-00001-of-01024`). This was raised in #409. 

3. Ideally, I still want to use `sky.Storage` for cloud paths in file_mounts. However, this edge case of mounting **objects** instead of **buckets** requires special handling. I don't think sky.Storage should be used for mounting single files since it breaks the semantics of sky.Storage. 

Decision: For now, we will stick to not using sky storage for cloud paths in file_mounts and instead copy them using gsutil/aws. We should discuss how cloud objects (files on buckets) should be treated differently from cloud object stores (buckets).

Tested:
- [x] `sky launch -c min examples/minimal.yaml`.
- [x] `examples/run_smoke_tests.sh` (modulo Azure bug #413)

title: Fix `check_local_gpus`
body:
Fixes #410 

Now the function additionally checks if the `nvidia-smi` toolkit actually works by seeing its return code.
If the machine has a GPU, `nvidia-smi` will return successfully.
Otherwise, `nvidia-smi` returns:
```bash
NVIDIA-SMI has failed because it couldn't communicate with the NVIDIA driver. Make sure that the latest NVIDIA driver is installed and running.
```

title: Use an AMI that has ray already installed to speedup the provision
body: Currently, it still takes quite a long time to install ray after the instances are launched. We can use an AMI that ray is already installed to further reduce the time from `sky launch` to the user can actually `ssh` into the cluster.

title: Decouple `ray up` and user's file_mounts / setup
body:
As mentioned in #400, our previous implementation has the user's file_mounts / setup coupled with the `ray up`. That makes it hard for us to have fine-grained control of them, make the cluster available as soon as it launched, and get rid of bugs of ray autoscalar. This PR aims to decouple them, implementing the proposal in #400.

Tested:
- [x] `sky launch -c min examples/minimal.yaml`.
- [x] `examples/run_smoke_tests.sh` (without #413 `azure-start-stop.yaml` and #409 `using_file_mounts.yaml`)
- [x] ctrl-c during file_mounts / setup, to see if user can ssh into the instance

Central place can be, for example, `~/sky_logs/<unique across user/run>` or `/tmp/sky_logs/<unique across user/run>`.  This avoids polluting many directories.

title: [Logging] Multiple `Shared connection closed` messages

labels.name: duplicate
labels.description: This issue or pull request already exists

body:
During provisioning and setting up (caused by file_mounts and setup), there will be many `shared connection closed` messages, which is confusing to the user. There are two possible solutions:
1. Skip this message in our logging redirection function (one line code modification).
2. As mentioned in #400, we handle the file_mounts and setup by ourselves, so that we can control the logging more precisely.

title: [Doc] Add workdir in `hello_sky.yaml`

labels.name: duplicate
labels.description: This issue or pull request already exists

body: We need to add something like `workdir: .`, so that the user can know there is a `workdir` field from the quick-start example? This was an observation from the first user directly modifying the `hello_sky.yaml` for his own project, without knowing the `workdir` field.

title: [Job] The non-detached mode makes the user thought ctrl-c will kill the program
body:
Our current default behavior of `sky launch` and `sky exec` will stream the logs to the console. This will make the user afraid to ctrl-c, don't knowing whether it will kill the job.

One possible solution is to make the detached mode as default, and let the user run `sky logs` by themselves to stream the logs.

title: [Storage] User tends to use the default file_mounts
body:
Though we support cloud storage for large files, the user tends to use the default one. The reasons might be the following:
1. The default file_mounts is more intuitive.
2. We do not have a good doc to guide the user using cloud storage.

A quick fix could be finding a better place (maybe in the quick start) to tell the user to use the cloud storage in our document.

title: Proposal for provision pipeline
body:
We currently had quite many problems with `ray up` not updating file_mounts (mostly for multi-node), the logging is not informative enough #384, long wait time during file_mounts for large files, `workdir` problem in #389, ssh config set too late problem #385, and also the problem when the user's setup fails the cluster will remain `INIT` state (not distinguishing the whether the instance is successfully launched or not).

The following is my proposal for a new API:

For the Backend, we add a new `setup` function, and during execution, we add this `setup()` after the `sync_file_mounts` function. The `provision` function is now only responsible for launching the instances and setup ray, just like the first step of gang_scheduling. Also, before the provisioning, our backend can try `ray exec handle.yaml -- ray status` to check the availability of the cluster and skip the `ray up` if ready. All the user-customized file_mounts and setups are then handled by our own functions.

title: README example: change `K80:4` to `V100:1`
body:
Reasons:
- `K80:4` is not available on AWS, arguably the most common cloud our target users use, so they will hit resource unavailable
- `V100:1` is available on all three clouds and is a popular GPU

title: Support 'name:cnt' accelerators spec in YAML
body:
Closes #386: Left the old spec (dict) in there, but updated all documentation to encourage the new format.  The former is now a hidden format that shouldn't be used (existing yamls should still work).

Closes #383.

Fixes #373: 'sky start/down' should error out.

title: [Other] Sky Status `-v`
body: Instead of `sky status -a`, it'd be cool to have `sky status -v` instead, as verbose describes `Showing all information in full` better.

title: [Storage] Dataset Symlink Issue
body: Sky will not upload dataset/sync file mount IF the dataset path is a symlink to the actual dataset path.

title: [Storage] User Dataset: Millions of Small Files
body:
It is possible that the user's dataset consists of millions of SMALL files. 

Uploading to the Bucket in this case is tedious. It'd be better to chunk these files and upload them instead.

title: [Storage] Uploading Model Checkpoints from VM onto Bucket
body:
So far Sky Storage allows for 1) Uploading from Local to Cloud Store, 2) Downloading from Cloud Store to Cloud VM.

A very common case in ML is to save checkpoints. These checkpoints should be automatically uploaded to the Cloud Store.
This is outside 1) and 2) and falls under 3) Uploading from Cloud VM to Cloud Store.

Being able to mount a bucket onto the VM will greatly mitigate this task.

title: [Storage] Large Dataset inside `workdir`
body:
In some cases, users will have the entire dataset e.g. `/tmp/imagenet` in their work directory! This is extremely bad since syncing the work directory will hanging if the dataset is big. 

Potential Fix: Some mechanism to determine the size of the workdir and throw warning if workdir is too big. Sky can also automatically manage big folders and move them onto S3 Store.

title: [Sky Launch] `bash setup.sh` in setup will fail to activate conda environment
body:
It is common for initial users to run their setup script in their work directories and type `bash setup.sh` to setup their repos. The installation via the `setup.sh` on the cloud differs from installing locally via `bash setup.sh`. 

This is also an issue with our Horovod Example (where `setup.sh`: https://github.com/michaelzhiluo/horovod-tf-resnet/blob/main/setup.sh)

According to @gmittal, this is because Sky moves `setup.sh` to a larger, official `setup.sh` and loses some important state.

Quick Fix: `bash -i setup.sh`

title: [Sky Launch] `workdir` Not Syncing to Cloud
body:
1st time running `sky launch`: `Workdir` in YAML is not specified -> Workdir is not on cloud (as expected)
2nd time running `sky launch`: `Workdir` in YAML is not specified -> Workdir is not on cloud (as expected)
...
nth time running `sky launch`: User fills in `Workdir` in YAML -> Workdir is not on cloud (BAD)

To be precise, Ray up does not sync working directory after the nodes are provisioned.

title: [Sky Launch] User's `workdir` name should match Cloud's `workdir` name
body: If the user's setup script installs their own `workdir` (such as `pip install -e .`), the installed packaged will be named `sky_workdir` because Sky uploads the user's work directory under `sky_workdir`.

title: Resource Specification for # of CPUs
body:
Sky currently supports users requesting X amount of GPUs/TPUs, e.g. 
```
resources:
  accelerators:
    V100: 8
```
Users should also be able to specify how many CPU cores they want, e.g.
```
resources:
  cores: 16
  accelerators:
    V100: 8
```
Additional changes are needed to the optimizer (to consider this additional resource constraint). In additional, while Google decouples # of CPUs and # of GPUs, AWS advertises their GPUs in fixed packages of (CPUs, GPUs) (e.g. `p3.2x (16 CPU, 1 V100), 3.8x, ...`), which is not as flexible as Google's model. The optimizer needs to account for this and select the right packages in AWS that meet the user's constraint.

title: [Sky Launch] Support Slurm Syntax for GPUs in YAML
body:
In Slurm, users can specify their GPUs for their batch jobs:
```#!/bin/bash
#SBATCH --account=def-someuser
#SBATCH --gres=gpu:1              # Number of GPUs (per node)
#SBATCH --mem=4000M               # memory (per node)
#SBATCH --time=0-03:00            # time (DD-HH:MM)
./program                         # you can use 'nvidia-smi' for a test
```
For Sky, the Slurm syntax is equivalent to `V100:8`. While this feature is available for the CLI (e.g. `sky exec mycluster --gpus V100:1 -d -- python train.py --lr 1e-3`), the YAML does not support Slurm syntax, in particular, the `resources/accelerators` field. This example should work below once SLURM syntax is implemented,
```
resources:
  cloud: aws
  accelerators: 'V100:8'
```

title: [Sky Launch] SSH to Machine during first run of `sky launch`
body:
It looks like the steps that allow the user to authenticate and access the machine (modifications to `~/.ssh/config`) are done after `ray up` is complete. This raises a bigger issue, what if the user wants to `ssh` to the machine in the middle of `ray up`.

This is a likely case, since initial users may lose patience when `sky launch` is taking too long and want to see what is wrong with their provisioned node.

Potential Fix (suggested by @Michaelvll): `ray up` with empty config to setup `~/.ssh/sky-key` and `~/.ssh/config` as soon as possible. Then, `ray up` with full yaml.

title: [Logging/Sky Launch] Highlight Error Message from User Setup/Run Commands
body: When Sky is provisioning machine and running the user's `setup/run` commands in the yaml file, it is difficult for initial users to find the error message in their setup or run script amidst all the logs. Hence, it is a good idea to highlight the errors.

title: [Logging] YAML Indentation 3 Space in Docs
body:
Every YAML in our docs, https://sky-proj-sky.readthedocs-hosted.com/, has 3 spaces for indentation; As opposed to `README.md`, the indentation is 2 spaces. 

Initial users will copy paste the YAML and modify it. 3 spaces make it difficult to modify  YAML, as it conflicts with the spaces in the `Tab` key.

title: [Sky-Setup] Installing Azure-CLI takes too long
body: `pip install azure-cli` takes too much time. This is because `azure-cli` has over 50 dependencies. Below is an image of how long it took to run Azure installation on `Blaze`: Potential Fix: Figure out the minimal set of packages in `azure-cli` that works for Sky.

title: [Sky-Setup] `workdir` in Quick-start Example
body:
In the Sky docs, https://sky-proj-sky.readthedocs-hosted.com/en/latest/getting-started/quickstart.html, the minimal `hello_sky.yaml` examples does not have `workdir` specified in the YAML. Initial users have trouble moving their repo onto the Cloud machines if `workdir` is not specified (this is also difficult to debug).

Also needs to be changed in `README`.

title: [Sky-Setup] Installing Sky with Python < 3
body:
Sky does not work for python versions under `3.6`.  Initial users are not aware of the right python version.

Potential Fix: There are several potential fixes.
First is to make it very obvious in the documentary that the user needs python > 3.6.
Second, return a descriptive error (e.g. `InstallationError: Sky works for only python>3.6`)in `setup.py` if the user's python is too old.

title: [Sky-Setup] `pip install .[all]`
body:
`pip install .[all]` is unintuitive for new users (except those who have used `pip install ray[all]` for Ray). That's beside the point; users need a way to quickly learn all the different pip installs.

In particular in `setup.py`, not all users know about the additional pip install keys. (`aws, azure, gcp, docker`)

![Screen Shot 2022-02-19 at 11 08 36 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20640975/154832411-3dd4a80d-0f1e-4620-9beb-a9e2b515b1e6.png)


Potential Fix: Improve documentation on the different pip keys or simplify installation (automatically do all)

title: [Sky-Setup] Git Clone Documentation Error
body:
In the README and Docs installation section, the user clones the repo with `git clone ssh://git@github.com:sky-proj/sky.git`

Originally, there was a typo to this command. Now, there is an additional bug:

```
(ray) michaelluo@MacBook-Pro-2 walker % git clone ssh://git@github.com:sky-proj/sky.git
Cloning into 'sky'...
ssh: Could not resolve hostname github.com:sky-proj: nodename nor servname provided, or not known
fatal: Could not read from remote repository.
```

Quick Fix: Replace with `git clone https://github.com/sky-proj/sky.git`

title: Cannot install on Apple Silicon due to grpcio issue
body:
Our package as is won't install on Apple Silicon due to grpcio (imported by Ray) compatibility issues. The current workaround I've been using is: `pip uninstall grpcio; conda install grpcio`, but I'm hoping either grpcio/ray finds a way to fix this soon.

Until then should we add a section to our documentation about this for Apple Silicon users?

title: Fix SSH typo for git clone in README
Symlinks break Windows compatibility
body: #342 moves setup.py to `sky/setup_files` and creates a symlink for setup.py at the root. However, using symlinks breaks sky compatibility on filesystems that don't support symlinks (ntfs, windows). Instead of having symlinks for setup.py, can we put the actual file at root? @suquark wdyt?

title: Restore README to the original place
body: Now we pick the long description from README, and the setup procedure no longer depends on README (it's how numpy works). We can restore README to project root and remove the softlink.

title: Sky down exits silently
body: `sky down` without any parameters exits silently. Is it intended?

title: Fix Azure credential errors on AWS
body:
AWS provides managed identity for Azure, but it is not setup properly by default. This interferes with azure-cli credentials and causes failures. We disable it to give way to azure-cli credentials.

Closes #364

title: Remove typo from README
body: Remove RST :code: left in

title: Limit grpcio version for #369
body:
The latest `grpcio==1.44.0` will cause the problem mentioned in #369 . This PR limits the version in `setup.py`.

Tested:
- [x] `sky launch -c min ./examples/minimal.yaml`

title: Doc html pollutes the git history
body:
As mentioned in #341, the doc html is polluting the git history. Currently, there are two solutions:
1. Wait until our repo being public and remove all the HTMLs.
2. Do something like the following proposal.

For my own homepage (also Github Pages), I store all the htmls to another branch. Whenever I run `make deploy`, it will copy the changes in the source branch to `gh-pages` branch and build it there and force push it to the `gh-pages` branch on github. My website will then publish that `gh-pages` branch. In that way, my other branches' git history will not be polluted. Here is the bash script for reference.
```bash
#!/usr/bin/env bash

# Run this script to deploy the app to Github Pages

# Parse cmd arguments

SRC_BRANCH="master"
DEPLOY_BRANCH="gh-pages"

USAGE_MSG="usage: deploy [-h|--help] [-u|--user] [-s|--src SRC_BRANCH] [-d|--deploy DEPLOY_BRANCH]"

while [[ $# > 0 ]]; do
    key="$1"

    case $key in
        -h|--help)
        echo $USAGE_MSG
        exit 0
        ;;
        -u|--user)
        SRC_BRANCH="source"
        DEPLOY_BRANCH="master"
        shift
        ;;
        -s|--src)
        SRC_BRANCH="$2"
        shift
        ;;
        -d|--deploy)
        DEPLOY_BRANCH="$2"
        shift
        ;;
        *)
        echo "Option $1 is unknown."
        echo $USAGE_MSG
        exit 0
        ;;
    esac
    shift
done

# Exit if any subcommand fails
set -e

echo "Deploying..."
echo "Source branch: $SRC_BRANCH"
echo "Deploy branch: $DEPLOY_BRANCH"

# read -r -p "Do you want to proceed? [y/N] " response
response=y
if [[ ! $response =~ ^([yY][eE][sS]|[yY])+$ ]]
then
    echo "Aborting."
    [[ "$0" = "$BASH_SOURCE" ]] && exit 1 || return 1
fi

# Check if there are any uncommitted changes
if ! git diff-index --quiet HEAD --; then
    echo "Changes to the following files are uncommitted:"
    git diff-index --name-only HEAD --
    echo "Please commit the changes before proceeding."
    echo "Aborting."
    [[ "$0" = "$BASH_SOURCE" ]] && exit 1 || return 1
fi

# Switch to source branch (creates it if necessary from the current branch)
if [ `git branch | grep $SRC_BRANCH | tr ' ' '\n' | tail -1` ]
then
    git checkout $SRC_BRANCH
else
    git checkout -b $SRC_BRANCH
fi

# Checkout DEPLOY_BRANCH branch
if [ `git branch | grep $DEPLOY_BRANCH` ]
then
  git branch -D $DEPLOY_BRANCH
fi
git checkout -b $DEPLOY_BRANCH

# Build site
bundle exec jekyll build

# Delete and move files
find . -maxdepth 1 ! -name '_site' ! -name '.git' ! -name 'CNAME' ! -name '.gitignore' -exec rm -rf {} \;
mv _site/* .
rm -R _site/

# Push to DEPLOY_BRANCH
git add -fA
git commit --allow-empty -m "$(git log -1 --pretty=%B) [ci skip]"
git push -f -q origin $DEPLOY_BRANCH

# Move back to SRC_BRANCH
git checkout $SRC_BRANCH

echo "Deployed successfully!"

exit 0
```
